title: Ticket #3419: condor_submit won't expand macros directly inserted into job classad
description:
You can specify macros for expansion in your submit file in the form $(Name). This works for "normal" submit file entries, but not for things directly inserted into the job's classad using +Name=blah.

For example, given a submit file of: 

universe=vanilla
requirements=false
executable=/bin/date
arguments=foo=$(foo) qux=$(qux)
foo=foo
+qux="qux"
queue

Actual output: 

sh-4.1$ condor_submit submit
Submitting job(s).
1 job(s) submitted to cluster 45.
sh-4.1$ condor_q -format '%s\n' Args 45
foo=foo qux=

Expected output: 

sh-4.1$ condor_submit submit
Submitting job(s).
1 job(s) submitted to cluster 45.
sh-4.1$ condor_q -format '%s\n' Args 45
foo=foo qux=qux

This was an actual nuisance, as I was setting a variable used by the machine's requirements, and that I had done so I wanted to pass to the arguments. I wanted to say something like: 

arguments=--log-level=D_FULLDEBUG --identity=$(TrustedUser)

+TrustedUser="username"
queue

+TrustedUser="someoneelse"
queue

+TrustedUser="bob"
queue

but had to say: 

arguments=--log-level=D_FULLDEBUG --identity=username
+TrustedUser="username"
queue

arguments=--log-level=D_FULLDEBUG --identity=someoneelse
+TrustedUser="someoneelse"
queue

arguments=--log-level=D_FULLDEBUG --identity=bob
+TrustedUser="bob"
queue

This is more verbose and more prone to mistakes.

Tangentially related: Ticket #2091: Condor_submit should warn or fail if undefined macro used. If that was implemented, as least you'd be warned that it hadn't worked, instead of silently being an empty string.
remarks:
2013-Jan-08 20:30:42 by nwp:
Can you do 
arguments=foo=$(foo) qux=$$([qux])

2013-Jan-08 20:39:15 by nwp:
Why yes you can: 
executable = /bin/echo
universe = vanilla
arguments = $$([foo])
output = 3419.$(cluster).$(process).out
error = 3419.$(cluster).$(process).err
log = 3419.log
should_transfer_files = yes
when_to_transfer_output = on_exit
+foo = 1
queue

+foo = 2
queue
produces the expected output.
